Award.AwardTitle: Analyzing the Impacts of Non-Gaussian Errors in Gaussian Data Assimilation Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
The basis for most of the world's operational and research variational data assimilation (DA) is that all errors are Gaussian distributed. For synoptic-scale weather systems this assumption is a good approximation, however even at these large scales there some variables (e.g., positive-definite quantities such as relative humidity) cannot be properly characterized by assumed Gaussian error distributions. The impact of an imposed negative value for a positive-definite variable such as moisture is that an operational system DA system could fail to converge or otherwise yield an unstable numerical forecast or an unphysical model state. This Gaussian assumption is also present in retrieval systems that are based upon a maximum likelihood estimation (MLE) Bayesian-type approach. In some other Bayesian systems the moisture variable is assumed to be lognormally distributed and so the retrieved variable is the natural logarithm of the moisture variable. Both approaches introduce a bias into the analysis by finding the incorrect statistic to describe the probabilistic behavior of the random variable. In this project an alternative approach for non-Gaussian variables that combines a lognormal distribution with a Gaussian distribution, referred to as a mixed distribution, will be applied and evaluated. This mixed distribution allows for the retrieval and assimilation of Gaussian- and lognormally-distributed variables simultaneously. The mixed approach is different to the other two approaches in that it is finding the analysis mode with the correct covariances between the random variables, and not the mode of the best Gaussian approximation or the median of the lognormal distribution.

In the first stage of this effort, methods for determining where one can and cannot impose a Gaussian assumption for humidity within DA schemes, as well to quantify the impacts of such assumptions on retrieved quantities, will be developed. The second stage will investigate the impacts of assimilating retrieved data from the Gaussian assumption approach against the mixed distribution approach into a larger 3D- or 4D-VAR (variationally-based) approach as appropriate to the particular model system being evaluated [e.g., the NSF/NCAR-supported Weather Forecasting and Research (WRF) DA system]. The intellectual merit of this work will trace to the ability to better observe and assimilate moisture fields and develop an improved understanding of their interactions with other model-prognostic fields for a variety of dimensions of atmospheric prediction: synoptic, mesoscale and cloud resolving. Anticipated Broader Impacts of this effort will come through the ability to exert carefully motivated changes in DA schemes employed in larger numerical weather prediction systems, which would in-turn be expected to foster improved predictions of severe and/or extreme weather events. Broader impacts through education will occur through the mentorship and early-career development of a supported postdoctoral research associate, who will be trained in non-Gaussian DA methods as well as gain experience with retrievals and near-operational large DA systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated different aspects of changing the current Gaussian fits all versions of data assimilation theory, to one that was based upon a mixed Gaussian-lognormal based probability density function.  Data assimilation plays a vital role in how we obtain our weather and ocean forecasts.  There have been six outcomes from this project:

1) A version of incremental variational data assimilation that is based upon a new version of the tangent linear model referred to as the geometric tangent linear approximation and involves a multiplicative increment rather than an additive one.  This approach was tested against the current Gaussian fits all approach with the Lorenz 1963 and it was shown that the mixed approach beat the Gaussian when the errors associated with the observations were lognormally distributed.  

2) We have created the world's first mixed distribution based satellite brightness temperature 1DVAR retrieval system for temperature and mixing ratio.  It was compared against the Gaussian fits all and a logarithmic approach, where it was shown that we were able to obtain better fits to both moisture and temperature channels through the mixed approach. 

3) Another outcome of this project was a set of statistical tests to determine if there were an approach to detect if the dynamical flow changed distribution depending on the time of the year.  The test were able to show that there could be dynamical links between large scale synoptic features and the probability density function of the mixing ratio.  

4) During the implementation of the mixed distribution based retrieval system it became apparent that there was other properties that had been taken for granted from the Gaussian approach that did not apply to the lognormal configuration.  It was discovered that unlike with the Gaussian based VAR approaches, there are values for the background state such that either the mean, mode of the median based approach for the lognormal distribution based VAR that minimized the errors.  

5) While implementing and testing the different values for the background state against the different descriptive statistics it became apparent that there was a sensitivity to the first guess for the Newton-Raphson solver, if the background state was such that it compensated for all the other errors such that the minimum of the cost function was at the true state.  It was shown that if we were at 99% of the true optimal state then it did not matter where the first guess was chosen from, the accuracy stayed the same no matter which first guess was used.  However, as we approached the optimal state then the accuracy of the final answer started to depend on the value of the first guess. 

6) The last outcome from this work was a new linearization that enabled the theory for the buddy check observational quality control measure to be extended for lognormal based observational errors.

 

Intellectual Merits:  What this project has shown us is that it is possible to extend many different aspects of the Gaussian based variational data assimilation theory to a geometric based lognormal variational data assimilation  approach.  This now gives us the capability to adapt the current Gaussian based operational data assimilation systems to allow a possible more consistent probabilistic approach to numerical weather and ocean prediction. 

Broader Impacts:  The development of the mixed distribution retrieval system is applicable to many of the other geophysical disciplines, as well as the theory for the mixed additive and geometric incremental VAR, where many of the world's operational numerical weather and ocean prediction centers us a Gaussian only incremental scheme.  The detection algorithm again was not dependent on meteorological dynamics and is applicable across the sciences.

The discovery of optimal values and then zones of values for the background state, such that the inverse of the cost function is at the true state is important for all applications of variational based data assimilation schemes as it informs us of areas where we need to be careful of the descriptive statistic that we are seeking.  This combined with the chaotic behavior of the solver are important and these are new criteria that a data assimilation user most consider when going non-Gaussian.

Finally the new quality control measures are important for the future development of the mixed distribution approach for the operational centers.  If we are going to use the lognormal approach then we need to screen the observational errors to be consistent with that distribution, otherwise important observations could be incorrectly screened out, which could have adverse affects on the forecasts.
